Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Microbiome for improving salt stress tolerance in crops
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to provide an innovative approach to improve crop tolerance using novel seed treatments. To feed the growing world population (estimated 9.8 billion by 2050), global food production must increase by 70%, while reducing impact on land use, the environment, and ecosystems. However, high salinity conditions and drought have reduced the potential yield of crops; furthermore, the excessive application of fertilizers is disrupting global nitrogen and phosphorus cycles, reducing biodiversity, and causing aquatic pollution. This project will develop a technology to promote crop growth through improved stress tolerance and nutrient acquisition. The adoption of more sustainable agricultural practices could help farmers in increasing their profitability and reduce costs. This project will offer an effective solution to 570 million farms around the world for food production. By improving crop yield, the project could help address the economic loss of more than $27 billion/year in the US due to unproductive farmland. <br/><br/>The proposed project will generate innovative endophyte-based formulations for seed treatments to improve tolerance to abiotic stress. Seeds will be coated with a mixture of highly characterized safe (non-pathogenic) endophytic bacteria and yeast strains in formulation with selected osmoprotectants and prebiotics that improve the survivability and efficacy of the selected microbes. The bio-inoculants will improve crop tolerance to salinity stress while supporting nitrogen fixation and mineral nutrient acquisition. This project will validate the feasibility of this approach on treatments for selected vegetable seeds. First efforts will be dedicated to obtaining stable seed treatment formulations with a high shelf-life when used at scale in parallel with fungicide and insecticide treatments. The ability of bio-inoculant formulations to increase tolerance to salinity will be validated in the greenhouse. Finally, the performance of the most optimal formulation will be tested in a small field trial under high salinity conditions to validate its ability to increase crop yield and quality.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Existing biological seed treatment solutions in the market include active ingredients, comprising microbes such as fungi, bacteria, and plant extracts available in both liquid and powder form. Biological seed treatment helps the crops grow better as it acts as a bio-stimulant to minimize biotic/abiotic stress and boosts the immune system to fight against plant pathogens. Currently, the market is filled with larger agrochemical companies that use such biological seed treatments mainly for pest control and fertilization. However, these products mostly target biotic stresses and lead to a slow increase in crop yields. They rely on poorly selected microbes with limited shelf life and fail to deliver an appropriate number of living microbes to the plant.

Drought and salinity are the most destructive abiotic stresses, reducing average yields for most major crop plants by more than 50%. The urgent need to increase crop plant resiliency with dynamically changing environmental conditions prompted Intrinsyx to address also the abiotic stress tolerance in crop. Intrinsyx Bio is developing a new approach to Agricultural Microbiology based on the identification of microbes for targeted applications combined with the use of 'soft chemistry' that allows efficient delivery, improved microbes survivability and product stability.

Intrinsyx Bio is generating innovative endophyte-based formulations to be used as seed treatments to improve tolerance to abiotic stresses. Seeds are coated with a mixture of highly characterized safe (non-pathogenic) endophytic bacteria and yeast strains in formulation with selected osmoprotectants and prebiotics (elicitation chemistry) that improve the survivability and efficacy of the selected microbes. The Bio-Inoculants entrance occurs via colonization of cracks or fissures naturally available in the epidermic tissue of seeds (a crack-entry mechanism) and promotes plant growth by conferring tolerance to abiotic stresses, increasing the crop yield and the quality of nutrition. At the same time, Intrinsyx Bio-Inoculants will support nitrogen fixation, phytohormone production, and nutrient acquisition (mobilizing insoluble phosphorus in the soil for uptake). The values of Intrinsyx's bio innovations include increased crop yield, sustainable, cost-effective farming practices, reduced use of chemical fertilizer, scalability, and longer shelf-life of the microbial bioinoculants (6-12 months).

Intrinsyx Bio products introduce two main innovations in Agriculture Microbials: (1) Selective approach. Intrinsyx achieved targeted identification of safe (non-pathogenic) endophytic bacterial and yeast strains that support nitrogen fixation (without the need of root nodule), phytohormone production, and enhanced nutrient acquisition allowing growth under high salt conditions. (2) Elicitation chemistry. Intrinsyx Bio formulations combine the selected strains with biological elicitors that provide adaptation and stability of the bio inoculants under various unfavorable environmental conditions such as excess salinity. Intrinsyx uses a combination of osmoprotectants and prebiotics to allow longer shelf-life stability of the bio-inoculants and improved survivability over time.

To determine the technical and commercial feasibility of Intrinsyx Bio endophyte inoculants as seed treatments to improve crop tolerance to salinity stress, the SBIR Phase I study was implemented. In this study, endophytic formulations were developed and greenhouse tested pertaining to (i) microbial survivability on the seed for measuring stability and (ii) compatibility with other agricultural seed treatment products (fungicide and insecticide), were carried out. Further, the most promising endophyte formulations were tested to confirm their salinity stress tolerance benefits in field trials with two sample plant species: Lettuce and Broccoli. The long-term testing on the microbes on the seed demonstrated reduced survivability over time, however, it demonstrated that the microbes were still alive on the seeds. Also, in the seed germination evaluation of broccoli and lettuce, the results demonstrated that the treatments did not impede germination or harm either lettuce or broccoli seedlings. While there was high variability in the results between both these crops, a clear trend was observed in increased lettuce crop salinity tolerance by using the endophyte seed treatments. A remarkable increase in dry weight of shoot biomass compared to the control was observed in high salt conditions, which embarks the success of the selected seed treatments comprising endophyte formulations. Thus, Intrinsyx Bio's endophyte bioinoculants demonstrate a reliable biological seed treatment for the improvement of salinity tolerance in seed plants. The impact of increased crop stress tolerance obtained by Intrinsyx bioinoculants will expand its use on other seasonal crops with multiple growing seasons and under other stress conditions such as drought.
